docs.lead_paragraph: Having an unhappy youth or a bleak middle age has little effect on whether a man will be happy during retirement, according to a new study. And a prosperous adulthood is no assurance of contentment after one's working years have ended. Even a large pension, the study found, is less important in assuring contentment than generally believed. In other words, being retired, for many people, may be the start of something entirely new.

headline.main: Retirement Contentment In Reach for Unhappy Men

docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth J Mukamal, Harvard University associate professor of medicine, leads study that finds men can enjoy retirement even if they did not enjoy earlier stages in life; research, which is published in American Journal of Psychiatry, suggests that retirement may be start of something new; holds that key factor in happiness is learning how to engage in activities that are gratifying without financial reward (M)
docs.snippet: A prosperous adulthood is also no assurance of contentment after one's working years have ended.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have found strong evidence that adenotonsillectomy -- the surgery to remove the tonsils and adenoids -- can help relieve childhood behavioral or attention problems, including attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D. Although the surgery has become less common with antibiotics, more than 400,000 children under 15 have their tonsils, adenoids or both removed every year, according to estimates by the Metropolitan Insurance Company. About half of the patients undergo the procedure to control chronic throat or ear infections. The rest have the operation to relieve breathing difficulty or nighttime sleep apnea, a serious disorder in which the sleeping child briefly stops breathing during the night.

headline.main: Tonsil-Adenoid Surgery May Help Behavior, Too

docs.abstract: Dr Ronald D Chervin, University of Michigan associate neurology professor, leads study on possible link between sleep disorders and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder in children; research, which is published in journal Pediatrics, suggests that symptoms of ADHD can be reduced through improved sleep health; looked at children who had operation to have tonsils or adenoids removed either for chronic sleep apnea or to curb infections; finds ADHD improved when children experienced fewer sleep interruptions (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers have found strong evidence that adenotonsillectomy -- the surgery to remove the tonsils and adenoids -- can help relieve childhood behavioral or attention problems, including attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Play hooky, disappear for the weekend, have a fling, binge-shop like a Wall Street divorcée. Spontaneity can be a healthy defiance of routine, an expression of starved desire, some psychologists say. Yet for scientists who study mental illness and addiction, impulsive behavior -- the tendency to act or react with little thought -- has emerged as an all-purpose plague.
docs.abstract: Janine D Flory, Mount Sinai School of Medicine psychologist, leads study to help explain how impulsive tendencies develop and what factors make people act destructively in certain situations; research, which is published in Journal of Psychiatric Research, connects activity in prefrontal areas of brain with impulsive behavior; finds that in humans impulsive actions peak during adolescent years; study may help doctors better understand addictive behaviors; drawing; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Researchers are beginning to identify why one person's spontaneity is another's descent into self-destruction.
